notes:
1. Definition

Hot working refers to the plastic deformation of metals and alloys at a temperature above their recrystallization temperature. Recrystallization is a process in which deformed grains are replaced by a new set of defect-free grains that nucleate and grow until the original grains have been entirely consumed.

2. Key Characteristics

  • Large Deformations: The metal has a low yield strength and high ductility at these temperatures, allowing for very large shape changes with relatively low forces.
  • No Strain Hardening: The recrystallization process occurs simultaneously with the deformation, preventing the material from becoming harder and more brittle (strain hardening).
  • Improved Properties: Hot working can refine the grain structure, reduce porosity, and improve the toughness and ductility of the metal.

3. Disadvantages

  • Poor Surface Finish: High temperatures cause oxidation and scaling on the metal surface.
  • Low Dimensional Accuracy: Due to thermal expansion and contraction, it is difficult to achieve precise dimensions.

4. Common Hot Working Processes

  • Forging: Shaping metal using localized compressive forces (hammering or pressing).
  • Rolling: Reducing the thickness of a workpiece by passing it between two rollers.
  • Extrusion: Pushing a workpiece through a die of a desired cross-section.

solvedExamples.question: Hot working of a metal is performed at a temperature that is:
solvedExamples.explanation: The defining characteristic of hot working is that the deformation takes place at a temperature high enough for recrystallization to occur concurrently, which relieves strain hardening.

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following is an advantage of hot working compared to cold working?

options.text: Lower forces and power are required.

solvedExamples.explanation: At elevated temperatures, the metal is softer and more ductile, meaning it requires significantly less force to achieve large deformations compared to cold working.
